One-lung ventilation

One-lung ventilation is indicated for….

Surgical access : VATS, TAAA,
Pneumonectomy / lobectomy, oesophagectomy, bronchial surgery,
mediastinal surgery.

infection, haemorrhage

Protect sick lung :

● Unilateral cyst/bulla

● Unilateral bronchial lavage

Improve ventilation/gas exchange :

● Bronchial injury

● B-P fistula

● Hypoxia due to unilateral lung disease

Management of hypoxia during one-lung ventilation.

  1. Oxygenation/ventilation of the unventilated lung :

● Increase F I O2 to the ventilated lung (relatively ineffective because of the physiology of shunt ) xxx

● Low flow O2 for apnoeic oxygenation

● Interrupting surgery for intermittent ventilation of the lung

● Some thoracic surgery will be unaffected by continuous ventilation both lungs

  1. Decrease shunt flow by clamping pulmonary artery to unventilated lung

  2. Increase cardiac output . This improves tissue oxygen delivery, so the tissue oxygen extraction is less, so venous blood has a higher C v O2 ,
